awd_titl_txt: STEM CareerLaunch: Evaluating the Feasibility of a STEM Career-Based, Collective Impact Model on Youth in Boys & Girls Clubs
awd_abstract_narration:
Increased exposure to STEM content and career pathways during out-of-school time contexts can significantly extend STEM learning and aspirational interests among middle and high school youth. Using a collective impact approach, the STEM CareerLaunch pilot project tests the feasibility of redesigning a widely used, national youth and career focused program for and by the National Boys & Girls Clubs of America to extend STEM learning and promote awareness, interest, and readiness for STEM-related occupations among youth. STEM CareerLaunch integrates extant STEM programs, such as First Robotics, Girls Who Code and Jason Learning, with newly developed STEM content and opportunities to create and test a comprehensive STEM learning and career program for youth. The results of this pilot will inform a more expansive effort to bring STEM CareerLaunch to an already networked 4,000 Boys & Girls Clubs, reaching over four million youth from predominately underrepresented groups in STEM, and youth participating in other afterschool/summer program throughout the United States.

Approximately 100 youth and informal educators in Boys & Girls Clubs in Fitchburg and Leominster, Massachusetts will participate in this pilot feasibility study. A five-pronged approach will be instituted including: (1) high quality out of school time STEM programming, (2) connected STEM career education, (3) mentorship, (4) professional development for the informal educators, and (5) incentives such as internships and field experiences for youth participants. The developmental evaluation will focus on program implementation, participant outcomes, and scale-up. Data collection methods will include quantitative and qualitative approaches such as baseline student data, project tracking logs, retrospective surveys, focus groups, staff interviews, and observations.  A summative evaluation will also be conducted.

This endeavor is led by a collaborative partnership between the National Boys & Girls Clubs of America, Worcester Polytechnic Institute STEM Center, the Fitchburg and Leominster Public School Districts, and others. It is primarily funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. It is also co-funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program which is committed to better understanding and promoting practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, and or mathematics (STEM).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: Boys & Girls Club of Fitchburg and Leominster
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE BOYS & GIRLS CLUB OF FITCHBURG & LEOMINSTER - A NONPROFIT EDUCATIONAL CORPORATION

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Boys  Girls Club of Fitchburg and Leominster

por.por_cntn:
The Boys & Girls Clubs of Fitchburg and Leominster (BGCFL) worked with the  AISL grant under the Pilot and Feasibility Studies category to pilot the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) CareerLaunch Program, an Out-of-School Time (OST) work-based learning model designed to improve the awareness of, interests in, and readiness for STEM-related occupations.

The STEM CareerLaunch Program incorporated the following AISL program priorities into its approach: Enhancing Knowledge-building, Promoting Innovation, Advancing Collaboration, Strengthening Infrastructure and Building Capacity, and Broadening Participation.

STEM CareerLaunch met the needs of the underrepresented students served through: Culturally-relevant environment: BGCFL staff implemented the STEM OST activities were locally hired, many having grown up in the same neighborhoods as the youth to be served. Fifty percent of the instructors were women and minorities.  STEM Career Education, internships and mentorships were organizations based in the target communities. The project was mindful to incorporate professional diversity into the Career Education component. BGCFL sought out companies owned by minorities and women for field trips so participants could see that STEM professionals are people that look like them. High quality STEM learning through multiple evidence-based curricula: BGCFL will linked STEM related career education to the Boys & Girls Clubs of America’s national CareerLaunch curriculum. The research base of CareerLaunch was developed from the U.S. Department of Labor Secretary’s Commission of Achieving Necessary Skills (SCANS) report, which identified 11 core competencies that successful people bring to a job: 1. Making career decisions; 2. Using labor market information; 3. Preparing resumes; 4. Filling out applications; 5. Interviewing; 6. Completing tasks effectively, 7. Being consistently punctual; 8. Maintaining regular attendance; 9. Demonstrating positive attitudes and behaviors; 10. Presenting appropriate appearance; 11.Exhibiting good interpersonal relations.

STEM CareerLaunch made meaningful strides in Year 1, although there were several implementation challenges including: staffing, program consistency, educator orientation, educator training, communication about the CareerLaunch program, and a need for increased focus on STEM. In Year 2 and Year 3 these implementation challenges were not able to be addressed in any meaningful way, and other challenges emerged, all in large part due to the pandemic.

Following are the key learnings from the program:

❏     Customize community partners to participant interests, as well as gaps in their knowledge.

■      In surveys, it was clear that not all participating youths knew adults in some of the fields they were interested in for future careers. Finding guest speakers and mentors in these fields could be useful. 

■      Focus group youth participants also suggested making the guest speakers more relevant to their career interests.

 

❏     Find partners who model equity and inclusion.

■      It’s especially important, given the demographic of the club’s youth participants, that the youth participants see people who like them in positions of authority and expertise.

■      This can be addressed by courting Latino, Black, and women-led professional groups and organizations, as well as educators and other individuals (mentors, guest speakers, etc.) who represent equity and inclusion positive examples.

 

❏     Ensure educators participate fully in program professional development training.

■      Not all educators participated in DoS and WPI training. Ensuring that all educators, or as many as possible, participate in training is essential to being able to have an impact on educator STEM outcomes.

 

❏     Strengthen and formalize orientation to clarify roles and responsibilities of educators.

■      Offering a formal and regular orientation for educators about the STEM CareerLaunch program may serve to increase consistency and may even stimulate greater commitment in educators.

■      An essential piece of this orientation should be clearly communicating the boundaries and goals of the STEM CareerLaunch program, and how educators fit into this program.

 

❏     Experiment with course and field trip structure

■      When the pandemic allows a return to club-based, in-person programming, experiment with the two-hour classroom format that combined a Career Launch curriculum session with a STEM activity session.

■      STEM careers will become more interesting and understandable for youth participants when the classroom activities are closely connected both temporally and content-wise with field trips to STEM- focused companies and organizations.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Elizabeth Coveney
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Boys & Girls Clubs of Fitchburg and Leominster (BGCFL) worked with the  AISL grant under the  Pilot and Feasibility Studies category to pilot the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM)  CareerLaunch Program, an Out-of-School Time (OST) work-based learning model designed to improve  the awareness of, interests in, and readiness for STEM-related occupations.

The STEM CareerLaunch Program incorporated the following AISL program  priorities into its approach: Enhancing Knowledge-building, Promoting Innovation, Advancing  Collaboration, Strengthening Infrastructure and Building Capacity, and Broadening Participation.

STEM CareerLaunch met the needs of the underrepresented students served through: Culturally-relevant environment: BGCFL staff implemented the STEM OST activities were locally hired,  many having grown up in the same neighborhoods as the youth to be served. Fifty percent of the  instructors were women and minorities.  STEM Career Education, internships and  mentorships were organizations based in the target communities. The project was mindful to  incorporate professional diversity into the Career Education component. BGCFL sought out  companies owned by minorities and women for field trips so participants could see that STEM  professionals are people that look like them. High quality STEM learning through multiple evidence-based curricula: BGCFL will linked STEM related career education to the Boys & Girls Clubs of America’s national CareerLaunch curriculum. The  research base of CareerLaunch was developed from the U.S. Department of Labor Secretary’s  Commission of Achieving Necessary Skills (SCANS) report, which identified 11 core competencies that  successful people bring to a job: 1. Making career decisions; 2. Using labor market information; 3.  Preparing resumes; 4. Filling out applications; 5. Interviewing; 6. Completing tasks effectively, 7. Being  consistently punctual; 8. Maintaining regular attendance; 9. Demonstrating positive attitudes and  behaviors; 10. Presenting appropriate appearance; 11.Exhibiting good interpersonal relations.

STEM CareerLaunch made meaningful strides in Year 1, although there were several implementation challenges including: staffing, program consistency, educator orientation, educator training, communication about the CareerLaunch program, and a need for increased focus on STEM. In Year 2 and Year 3 these implementation challenges were not able to be addressed in any meaningful way, and other challenges emerged, all in large part due to the pandemic.

Following are the key learnings from the program:

❏     Customize community partners to participant interests, as well as gaps in their knowledge.

■      In surveys, it was clear that not all participating youths knew adults in some of the fields they were interested in for future careers. Finding guest speakers and mentors in these fields could be useful. 

■      Focus group youth participants also suggested making the guest speakers more relevant to their career interests.

 

❏     Find partners who model equity and inclusion. 

■      It’s especially important, given the demographic of the club’s youth participants, that the youth participants see people who like them in positions of authority and expertise.

■      This can be addressed by courting Latino, Black, and women-led professional groups and organizations, as well as educators and other individuals (mentors, guest speakers, etc.) who represent equity and inclusion positive examples.

 

❏     Ensure educators participate fully in program professional development training. 

■      Not all educators participated in DoS and WPI training. Ensuring that all educators, or as many as possible, participate in training is essential to being able to have an impact on educator STEM outcomes.

 

❏     Strengthen and formalize orientation to clarify roles and responsibilities of educators.

■      Offering a formal and regular orientation for educators about the STEM CareerLaunch program may serve to increase consistency and may even stimulate greater commitment in educators.

■      An essential piece of this orientation should be clearly communicating the boundaries and goals of the STEM CareerLaunch program, and how educators fit into this program.

 

❏     Experiment with course and field trip structure 

■      When the pandemic allows a return to club-based, in-person programming, experiment with the two-hour classroom format that combined a Career Launch curriculum session with a STEM activity session.

■      STEM careers will become more interesting and understandable for youth participants when the classroom activities are closely connected both temporally and content-wise with field trips to STEM- focused companies and organizations.
